results.title: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author
results.creator_credit: Harold Mantell, Ken Frankel and Films for the Humanities
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the drama”.
An abridged presentation in English of Pirandello’s play in which six characters seek to exchange their fixed, frozen form in art for the uncertainty of life, to distinguish between dramatic reality and dramatic illusion, between acting and artifice in real life, and between reality and truth. Narrated by Joseph Heller.
results.title_for_label: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author

results.title: The Zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to one of the world’s largest and most modern zoos, the Chicago Zoological Park. Animals are observed in areas simulating their natural habitat. Features polar and kodiak bears, lions, tigers, kanagaroos, baboons and a variety of familiar and not so familiar animals.

results.brief_description: Describes the zinc die casting industry of Australia, covering mining and refining and manufacture of a wide range of products.

results.title: The Yugoslav experiment
results.brief_description: This film uses newsreels and interviews to trace the history of Yugoslavia and shows the present day situation, (of 1977). Emphasis is placed on the Yugoslav economy, the agricultural and industrial systems, tourism and education.

results.title: The Yucatec Maya: a case study in marriage and the family
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Prompted by a desire to rediscover the extended family pattern of existence of his grandparents, anthropologist Hubert L. Smith lived for some time in the small Mexican village of Chican where the people still followed a traditional pattern of growing corn, beans and squash in jungle clearings, whilst being aware of the modern world nearby. In particular he studied one family and their attempt at sending the two youngest children away to school. The program successfully shows the reasons for the extended family in this environment and how it may have to change. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: The Young volunteers
results.creator_credit: Overseas Film & Television Centre and Peter Whale
results.brief_description: British Voluntary Service Overseas: shows orientation process for volunteers at a South London Teachers College. Includes scenes of volunteers in Mauritus, Lima (Peru), Korea, Malaysia, Kuala Lumpur, Tanzania.

results.title: The Young traveller in London
results.creator_credit: H Caspirius, INCA, Phoenix Films and Egon Larsen
results.brief_description: A young girl from the Scottish Highlands visits London for the first time, invited by her relatives. She expects to be shown round by them but discovers that they cannot agree on what to show her - for London means something different to them all; finally, as the film shows, she is taken on three separate trips.

results.title: The Young swimmer: the crawl stroke
results.brief_description: A demonstration of the fundamental principles pf the crawl stroke. A troop of championships swimmers demonstrates in turn the various aspects of the stroke - the attainment of balance by combined leg and arm movement; the correct leg action, observed from above, and below the water surface; breathing; arm action, the thumb entering the water first; co-ordinations of all movement; and the turn.

results.title: The Young protectors
results.brief_description: The Napier boys, interested in nature and wild life, make journeys to the bush and the coast, and walk to cape Kidnapers where they make surveys of the world’s only mainland gannet colony.

results.title: The Young person's guide to the orchestra
results.brief_description: This video focuses on the unique qualities of each instrument from it’s creation by the manufacturer to the musician who skilfully channels its sound. Narration by conductor Andrew Davis and interviews with world-acclaimed musicians, such as Yo-Yo Ma, provide insight and flavour to describe the instruments and their role in the sound of the orchestra. Suitable for Primary and Secondary level students.
